sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Metastatic colorectal cancer, In combination with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, irinotecan (FOLFIRI), in patients whose disease is resistant to or has progressed following an oxaliplatin-based regimen: 4 mg/kg IV infusion over 1 hour every 2 weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness in pediatric patients have not been established

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• elective surgery: interrupt therapy for at least 4 weeks prior to procedure; do not resume therapy for at least 4 weeks following a major surgical procedure and until the surgical wound is completely healed
  • hypertension, severe or recurrent: temporarily interrupt therapy until controlled, reinitiate and permanently reduce dose to 2 mg/kg IV; discontinue use if hypertensive crisis or hypertensive encephalopathy occur
  • proteinuria, 2 g/24 hours: interrupt therapy until proteinuria recovers to less than 2 g/24 hours and resume; if proteinuria recurs, interrupt therapy again until proteinuria recovers to less than 2 g/24 hours and reinitiate at permanently reduced dose of 2 mg/kg IV; discontinue use if nephrotic syndrome or thrombotic microangiopathy occur
  • geriatric: dose adjustment not necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Metastatic colorectal cancer, In combination with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, irinotecan (FOLFIRI), in patients whose disease is resistant to or has progressed following an oxaliplatin-based regimen

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Solution)
Severely compromised wound healing may occur; discontinuation is required. Suspend therapy for at least 4 weeks prior to elective surgery, and do not resume for at least 4 weeks following major surgery and until the surgical wound is fully healed. Severe and sometimes fatal hemorrhage, including gastrointestinal hemorrhage, has been reported; monitoring is required. Do not administer if severe hemorrhage. Gastrointestinal perforation including fatalities may occur; discontinuation is required.

1.title: Precautions
1.mono:
• compromised wound healing, severe, may occur; discontinuation required
  • hemorrhage, severe and sometimes fatal, including gastrointestinal, intracranial, and pulmonary hemorrhage has been reported; monitoring required; discontinuation required if severe
  • hemorrhage, severe; do not administer
  • gastrointestinal perforation including fatalities may occur; monitoring required; discontinuation required
  • surgery, elective; suspend therapy for at least 4 weeks prior to, and do not resume for at least 4 weeks following major surgery and until the surgical wound is fully healed after major or minor surgery
  • arterial thromboembolic events (eg, angina, transient ischemic attack, cerebrovascular accident) have been reported; discontinuation required
  • diarrhea and dehydration, grade 3 or 4, has been reported
  • fistulas of gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal sites have been reported; discontinuation required
  • geriatric patients; higher incidences of adverse events (eg, diarrhea, dizziness, asthenia, weight decrease, dehydration); monitoring for diarrhea and dehydration is recommended
  • hypertension, grade 3 or 4 including hypertensive crisis, has been reported; monitoring required; dosage adjustment and suspension or discontinuation of therapy may be needed
  • nephrotic syndrome has been reported; monitoring required; discontinuation required
  • neutropenic complications, grade 3 or 4, including febrile neutropenia and neutropenic infection, has been reported; monitoring required; interruption of therapy may be needed
  • reversible posterior encephalopathy syndrome involving neurologic sequelae and death has been reported; discontinuation of therapy required if confirmed
  • proteinuria, severe, has been reported; monitoring required; dosage adjustment and suspension of therapy may be needed
  • thrombotic microangiopathy has been reported; monitoring required; discontinuation required
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

3.title: Breast Feeding
3.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension, All grades (41%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Weight loss (32%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (27%), Decrease in appetite (32%), Diarrhea (69%), Stomatitis (50%)
  • Hematologic:Hemorrhage, All grades (38%), Leukopenia (78%), Neutropenia, All grades (67%), Thrombocytopenia (48%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised (50%), AST/SGOT level raised (62%)
  • Neurologic:Difficulty speaking (25%), Headache (22%)
  • Renal:Proteinuria, All grades (62%), Serum creatinine raised (23%)
  • Respiratory:Epistaxis (28%)
  • Other:Fatigue (48%), Infectious disease (46%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Angina, Hypertension, Grade 3 or 4 (grade 3, 19%; grade 4, 0.2%), Pseudoaneurysm
  • Dermatologic:Impaired wound healing (grade 3, 0.3%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal fistula (grade 3, 0.3%), Gastrointestinal hemorrhage, Gastrointestinal perforation (0.8%)
  • Hematologic:Arterial thrombosis (2.6%), Febrile neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 (4%), Hemorrhage, Grade 3 or 4 (3%), Neutropenia, Grade 3 or 4 (37%), Thrombotic microangiopathy, Venous thromboembolism (9%)
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (0.3%), Sepsis, Grade 3 or 4 (1.5%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident, Intracranial hemorrhage, Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (0.5%), Transient ischemic attack
  • Renal:Nephrotic syndrome (0.5%), Proteinuria, Grade 3 or 4 (8%)
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary embolism (5%), Pulmonary hemorrhage

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ziv-aflibercept binds to vascular endothelial growth factors VEGF-A, VEGF-B, and human PIGF-2 to inhibit the activation that produces neovascularization and vascular permeability.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Total body clearance, hepatic impairment: no change
  • Total body clearance, renal impairment: no change

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • vials are intended for single-use only; discard any unused product
  • withdraw calculated dose and dilute in NS or D5W to yield concentration of ziv-aflibercept 0.6 to 8 mg/mL
  • use diluted solution within 4 hours if stored under refrigeration
  • administer infusion over 1 hour through a 0.2 micron polyethersulfone filter
  • do NOT give as IV bolus
  • do NOT mix or administer with other products

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• evidence of disease response or stabilization indicates efficacy
  • CBC with differential; baseline and prior to initiation of each cycle
  • blood pressure; every 2 weeks during therapy or more frequently as clinically indicated
  • urine protein; via urine dipstick analysis and urinary protein creatinine ratio (UPCR) for development or worsening of proteinuria during therapy; obtain a 24-hour urine collection in patients with a dipstick of 2+ or more for protein or a UPCR greater than 1

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patient to immediately report signs or symptoms of arterial thromboembolic events (eg, angina pectoris, TIA, stroke).
  • Advise patient to report signs or symptoms of infection, bleeding, or hypertension.
  • Tell patient to consult with physician before having surgery or procedures (tooth extractions, biopsies) as drug may delay wound healing.
  • Recommend men and women use reliable contraception during therapy and for at least 3 months after the last dose.
  • This drug may cause decreased appetite, fatigue, headache, weight loss, dysphonia, stomatitis, and proteinuria.
  • Counsel patient to report diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration, or severe abdominal pain.
